metadata.titleEn: WATER: Dataset of ground truth measurements synchronizing with the airborne microwave radiometers (L&K bands) mission in the Linze grassland foci experimental area on Jul. 8, 2008
metadata.description:
The dataset of ground truth measurements synchronizing with the airborne microwave radiometers (L&K bands) mission was obtained along the sample lines 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6 of the Linze grassland foci experimental area on Jul. 8, 2008. 25 points at intervals of 100m were selected along each line.
    Simultaneous with the satellite overpass, numerous ground data were collected, soil gravimetric moisture, volumetric moisture, and soil bulk density by the cutting ring, the mean soil temperature from 0-5cm by the probe thermometer, the canopy and the land surface temperature by the hand-held infrared thermometer.
    See WATER: Dataset of setting of the sampling plots and stripes in the foci experimental area of Linze station for more information.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure soil moisture and temperature in remote sensing experiments?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to measure soil moisture and temperature in remote sensing experiments involves the use of an L&K band airborne microwave radiometer for aerial flights, combined with ground-based synchronous observations. In a specified observation area, multiple transects are laid perpendicular to the flight path, with sampling points spaced 100 meters apart. At each point, soil samples are collected using ring knives and dried to determine gravimetric and volumetric moisture content, as well as soil bulk density. Soil temperature at 0-5cm depth is measured using needle thermometers, and canopy and surface temperatures are recorded using handheld infrared thermometers.

Definition.Question: What are the methods used to collect soil moisture and temperature data in the context of L&K band airborne microwave radiometer ground-synchronous observations?
Definition.Answer: The methods used to collect soil moisture and temperature data include using a ring knife to obtain soil samples for gravimetric water content, volumetric water content, and soil bulk density after drying. A needle thermometer is used to measure the average soil temperature at 0-5cm depth, while a handheld infrared thermometer measures canopy and surface temperatures.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts on soil moisture and salinity retrieval algorithms if a dataset expands to include additional sampling points beyond the current 25 per strip with 100m spacing?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Expanding a dataset to include additional sampling points beyond the current 25 per strip with 100m spacing could enhance the granularity and spatial resolution of soil moisture and salinity measurements. This could lead to more accurate and reliable retrieval algorithms by providing more detailed ground truth data for validation. It may also help identify micro-variations in soil properties and better capture the heterogeneity of the observation area, potentially improving the precision of algorithm predictions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives of conducting ground-synchronous observations with L&K band airborne microwave radiometers in grassland areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective of conducting ground-synchronous observations with L&K band airborne microwave radiometers in grassland areas is to provide fundamental ground data for developing and validating algorithms that retrieve soil moisture and soil salinity using active microwave remote sensing.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are employed to obtain soil moisture and temperature measurements using L&K band airborne microwave radiometers, and what challenges might arise in synchronizing these with ground-based data collection methods?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedure involves conducting airborne flights with L&K band microwave radiometers over designated sampling transects. Ground-based data collection is synchronized with these flights across various transects, where measurements such as soil moisture, soil temperature, and surface temperature are recorded. Each transect has 25 sampling points spaced 100m apart. At each point, soil samples are collected using a soil corer for moisture and density analysis, while temperature is measured using a needle thermometer for soil and an infrared thermometer for canopy and surface temperatures. Challenges may include ensuring the accurate synchronization of airborne and ground data, dealing with environmental variability, and the precise calibration of instruments for consistent data collection.
